author: Coalminer

description.text: The heavy duty spool worked so well for me that in pretty much no time one entire color was gone. I was too lazy to change the filament on the spool for another color. Therefore I redesigned the part that holds the filament. It now has three slots to hold more colors and materials.

Slice and Print.
Use the 3mm holes in the arm to secure the first bit of filament onto the spool. Then  carefully wind the filament on the spool,making sure not to put to much strain on the spool. Do this for each slot and the spool will be fine.
I do not recommand putting filament on it which was originally wind up on a smaller spool. I tried this but this put way to much force on the arms of spool.

comments.text: Maybe add another lighter version of the hub and arms to brace the outside set of hooks.  I made the heavy duty spool myself, and the filament eventually tightened up and snapped the dovetail on one of the outer arms.   With 3 sets of filament, I can see the potential for breaking to be even greater.

My slicer (SKEINFORGE) does not allow to rotate designs before slicing. I do not know how to do this with the STL file. Any support you could give? BR, HArald

author: krozbolt

description.text:
This project is designed to fit the 410c DragonBoard from 96Boards. There are two variants of the box, the 'box' version places the screws that hold the box together outside the 410c, this is good for creating a large enough box to balance the 5" Waveshare display on.

The 'micro' box holds the 410c and nothing else, this is useful for building a pocket size system.

The 'box' can be extended vertically to hold a 2x16 LCD display, or a 5" HDMI display can be added in a seperate box. The seperate 5" LCD box can be mated to the 410c box with hinges or can be a standalone item only linked with the cables.

A 75x75mm VESA mount can be added to the micro-box to allow easy mounting onto a VESA monitor.

After several original Ultimaker extruder broke, we decided to do a mod of our own. It uses the original spring, the little bearing with its M3 bolt and nut that hold the bearing, and also the M3 bolt and nut that attach the extruder to the feeder mechanism from the original Ultimaker extruder. Edit 29.10.2013
Updated version of block part to make it fit better See http://www.3drucken.ch/2013/10/ultimaker-1-extruder-m4-guggelmod.html for more details.

Reused parts from original Ultimaker extruder:
1x spring
1x M3 bolt and nut that hold the spring
1x M3 bolt and nut that attach the extruder to the feeder mechanism New parts:
print 1x block ultimaker 1 extruder m4 gueggelmod (use upright position and touching buildplate support, 40% infill)
print 1x slider ultimaker 1 extruder m4 gueggelmod (40% infill)
1x M4 bolt 50mm (32-40mm should be enough)
3x M4 nut (you can save 2 if you use a shorter bolt)
1x bearing 12x8x3.5mm metal

print_settings.Notes:: A 250x250mm print size is needed for printing the mount base and the cross bars of the Dobsonian Mount. Otherwise, a regular 200x200mm printer is sufficient for the OTA and OTA support parts.

description.text:
This printable telescope features a collapsible OTA into a cakebox form that protects the optics, and a dobsonian mount that can be set up and ready for stargazing in less than 5 minutes. The OTA is also compatible with any other Vixen clamp mounts and the dovetail is also included inside the files.

3 Folders are available for download: OTA, OTA supports and Telescope Mount. The OTA prints the optical tube where the mirrors and critical scope contents are housed. The OTA supports feature the parts needed to hold the Makerbeams and secure them onto the OTA. The Telescope Mount is optional if you have your own tripod and mount, but is needed for new scope owners.

Assembly of the Hexonian 6 requires several different M4 screw lengths (15mm, 20mm, 25mm, 30mm, 35mm and 40mm), and nuts as well as M3 screws of 15mm and 20mm. One M6 screw of 45mm and 2 M6 nuts are required for the mount turntable. 5x Makerbeams of 10x10x500 are needed for the tube assembly, and 4x Makerbeam of 10x10x300 for the mount. The mount would require a printer that can print in dimensions of 250x250mm.

Please download the whole telescope in the link below:
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/6npb8drlcr5xybl/AADDPcqzfzDYUt_LMPlyndzQa?dl=0

Please purchase the mirror (150mm/6inch aperture, 750mm/f5) here:
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Newtonian-reflecting-telescope-D150-F750-D150F750-reflection-Objective-lens-Secondary-mirror/32621181033.html?spm=2114.10010108.1000014.1.pO7hwQ

Please purchase the 60mm rack and pinion focuser here:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/1-25-REFRACTOR-TELESCOPE-FOCUS-HOUSING-RACK-PINION-RACKS-OUT-TO-9-PLASTIC-/152187160918

(For smoother focusing, i recommend better quality focusers found on the internet. However, due to budgetary constraints, we used the cheapest possible one and made the adaptor for it to fit.)

(Instructions are to arrive later in PDF Format)

This item is sponsored and researched by Nanyang Technological University, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Making and Tinkering Course.

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

40% - 50% for most support parts

Notes:

A 250x250mm print size is needed for printing the mount base and the cross bars of the Dobsonian Mount. Otherwise, a regular 200x200mm printer is sufficient for the OTA and OTA support parts.

description.text:
this design places all delicate electronics inside the frames enclosed interior

top plate - FC (mounting holes for all common sized FC (naze, KK2 etc),battery strap points for 3s/4s battery

middle enclosure - space for 4x Esc & pdb or 4in1 esc (Qbrains etc)

Lower plate - space for Receiver(side plug versions only), Vtx, simpleOSD/MinimOSD, Battery alarm (visual holes in bottom for http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/New-Airsoft-Low-Voltage-Buzzer-For-2s-3s-Lipo-Battery-Alarm-UK-/262316042074?hash=item3d1341275a:g:vxsAAOSwEeFVOLI5), balance plug extension required

front mounting point for standard 600-700 Sony Tvl cam (tilted 25°)

rear mounting point for XT60 plug and VTX aerial connection (will require a small extension cable).

motor mount holes for common 250 race sized motors (1806's etc)

prop size max - 5"
3s battery max - 2200mah
4s battery max - 1400mah
hardware required -

10x m2x20 bolts
10x m2x10 bolts
balance plug extension (15-20cm)
vtx aerial extention cable (10cm)

update (29/07/2016)

details:-

frame size - exactly 250 (c/c motor)
motor size - 22mm-27mm
prop size - 4"-5"
frame weight - 190g (fully assembled frame only)

tested config:-

CC3d Nano
emax MT1806 2280kv
emax simon series 12a esc
5045 "indestructable" props
1000Tvl ir-cut cam
boscam ts353 tvx
Turnigy 1400Mah 4s
538g (fully assembled weight)

Results:-

stable on stock PID settings
stable acro characteristics
7mins heavy flight time
10mins light flight time

additional (04/08/2016):

Id like to apologise to anyone who has downloaded this design previous to this date and has encountered printing issues with the upper plate, somewhere between downloading it to my computer and uploading it to thingiverse the file had suffered corruption which was causing print errors, the problem has only just came to my attention and I have uploaded a fresh copy of the upper plate that I have test printed to confirm it is error free.

again I'm sorry I didn't catch this earlier.

additional (04/01/2017)

redesigned and re-tweeked all parts to accommodate the use of 3mm hex head bolts (easier to fit and stronger all-round)

changed topmost cover to accommodate a 1s battery (500mah max hubsan type/shape)

added adjustable angle mounting design for Eachine TX01/02/03 AIO fpv cam (runs off a single 1s lightweight battery)

added addition cable wiring access holes to better accommodate wiring through the frame levels without weakening overall structure.

addition of TX02 AIO has multiple benefits, along with the excellent signal strength,range and penetration of the TX02 there is the added side effect of weight reduction, with the AIO theres no need for additional Ubec,VTX,Antenna and wiring which dropped 50g immediately off the fully built frame with battery/RTF (RTF weight with original fpv gear - 548g, RTF weight with AIO and 1s battery - 497g), in addition to that there's less draw from flight battery so slight improvement to thrust and flight times

This is a replacement oil barrel for the board game "Power Grid" by Friedmann Friese and Rio Grande Games.
This is the piece that I dislike the most in the base game. It's a brown wooden cube. So I wanted to create a piece that more closely reflects the game's art for the coal resource, namely a large pyramidal pile.
I am not quite satisfied with the look of this piece on account of how it looks more like a pile of cannon balls than anything else.
Print in dark brown. Use the multiply module in Skeinforge to lay it out in a 5x5 grid. This will give you all the pieces you need to play and a couple extra.

comments.text: to make it look more like coal, i suggest using more natural shapes and placement. basically do not have them perfect spheres, and do not have them perfectly symmetric in placement. if you slightly deformed the spheres and rotates some then they would all look unique with out to much work, and then move them to a more haphazard stack to make it look like a pile as apposed to a pyramid. you said you where disappointed in how it looked so here is a suggestion from a random stranger, take it for what it is worth. and thanks for making them in the first place! go power grid!

description.text: I don't have much space in my workshop so I decided to put my new Ciclop scanner on a tripod. In addition to the printed scanner holder you will need 1x 1/4-20 hex nut. This is what the tripod connects to. At least in the US, tripods typically use a 1/4-20 thread to mount the camera. You also need 2x M3-10 screws and hex nuts. These secure the mount to the scanner. The screws just hold the acryllic using pressure, so you don't need to drill any holes, but don't use too much pressure or you will break the acryllic. There are also a couple of cable clips for organizing the cables

title: Ultimaker 2 Raspberry Pi and Pi Cam v2 Holders

description.text:
These are small, easily printable hangers which will hold a raspberry pi case and pi-cam v2 on an Ultimaker 2, 2+, or Extended.
The angle for the Pi Cam holder is fixed, but gives a full view of the active printing area and will show most of the build volume, even on Extended model Ultimakers. The clips are designed to hang a raspberry pi case with a 2-prong 40mm separated standard screw bracket.
Print the pi case hanger, then either glue, weld, or fuse the T-struts into the holes on the hanger. The hanger has been extended out to support the extra weight of the cables that would need to hang off a raspberry pi and connect it to power, network, and a printer.
The standard 6" ribbon cable that comes with the Pi Cam v2 will work, if the raspberry pi is hung on the front of your printer. If you want to hang it on the back or side, you will need to use a 12" or 18" cable. You will need to put at least one flat bend in the ribbon cable to use the camera clip, but the clip has a void to accommodate that bend and put less strain on the cable.

description.text:
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334917/ this goes a few steps further.

It is intended for dual extruder printers, although it can be made with a single extruder. A dual extruder will allow the labels to be in a contrasting colour. For single extruders, you can omit the label STL.

The SCAD file can generate a script (shell script, run under Unix or emulator) which when run, will call the SCAD file again and generate pairs of STLs for each atom.

I have tried to represent electronegativity by the length of a collar on each peg, although this could perhaps be improved. It would be great to be able to visually and intuitively show which bonds are higher energy!

Printer:

Prussa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

optional

Notes:

Some experimentation will get the best gap between the support and the atoms, and a little cleaning with a sharp knife and or small side cutters is needed.

Use side cutters and a sharp knife to clean away supports.

I also dip in acetone (for ABS) or chloroform (for PLA and PETG) to get a shiny finish

description.text:
The issue which comes with making a one piece hard plastic iPhone case is that a solid case will not work because the corners will not be able to pop into place since hard plastic is very rigid.

To get around this issue I designed this case with ribs, hence the name, which ensure full corner protection while allowing enough flexibility to pop the case on and off your phone. Video link follows. https://youtu.be/EQ47aBo5_pQ

The gaps in the ribs are just big enough to allow for flexibility yet also close enough to provide secure drop protection.

Yes

100%

description.text:
$1 Suggested Tip via PayPal Thanks!
For a small tip I'd be happy to customize these with your initials or any other modifications you'd like.

This is a tight fitting bolt puller for Ruger 22/45 Lite type pistols. As we all know, the Ruger 22/45 has some very sharp edges around where the bolt protrudes. This often leads to cuts or blood blisters if one tries to follow the bolt home with their fingers.

This Bolt Puller is sort of a hybrid design between the Tandemkross and Volquartsen bolt pullers.

This design requires makers to both tap and thread the clamp and puller respectively. This design is sized for 1/4-20 threading. So you will need a 1/4-20 tap and die for post processing this part.

I also advise printing at 100% infill since the stud on the puller is likely to shear off when you try to thread it if it is hollow with a lesser infill.

If you have any questions about the part, or if you would like to request a different thread size from 1/4-20, let me know in the comment section and I'll see what I can do.

UPDATE
By request I just recently added a Tactical Solutions style side charging handle option. See the files section. This one shouldn't require any tapping or threading or any other post processing like the others. However you should probably print it with supports "WHERE TOUCHING BUILD PLATE". Let me know how it works for you.

Printer:

MakerFarm Prusa i3v

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

Notes:

Print with the studs up in the air and with the clamp on its side.

Thread/tap with 1/4-20 tap and die.

The clamp is a little tricky to slip into position on the bolt. But it can be done by starting it rotated about 45 degrees off from its final position and carefully engaging both sides of the clamp on the bolt ears. Once it is started it can be turned the rest of the way with some pliers or an adjustable wrench. Just be careful not to scratch your pistol with any tools you use.

comments.text: This is fantastic man.  It's going on my list, just in case I ever get my POS 22/45 fixed.
comments.author: virto

comments.text: I obviously don't know what's up with your 22/45, but I will say that a lot of the "safety" features that Ruger put into the pistols definitely cause malfunctions. If you haven't already, look into mods like the Magazine Safety Delete and Loaded Chamber Indicator Delete from Tandemkross. I have both of those in my 22/45 Lite and it's been running really cleanly.

With 3 layers and 50% infill the rods appear to be extremely sturdy.  The mounts are much more tolerant, and anywhere between 20% and 50% infill should be adequate.

title: Twist-on Paper Towel Holder with Rod

description.text:
This is a paper towel holder with an included printed rod and easy twist-on loading. The rod goes all the way through so the paper towels are held securely while rotating freely (in contrast to the squeeze-grip holders). The left or right (your choice) side of the paper towel holder has a plastic tab that you twist half a turn with your fingers to slide out the rod and exchange the paper towels.

Since this is for standard paper towels which are approximately 28 centimeters long, I solved the rod printing problem by putting some modules for extendable threaded rods in my threading library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686322), which allow the rod to be printed in pieces and threaded together. Two pieces were enough for my printer's 175mm maximum height, but the OpenSCAD file has parameters and instructions for making the rod segments much shorter.

The mounting holes are cleared for M5, but should also work fine with M4, #8, or #10 screws. The four mounting holes should be placed about 24cm apart horizontally, and 3cm apart vertically. Measure twice, make holes once, and use drywall anchors if mounting into drywall. Leave clearance on either the left or the right for sliding the rod out to exchange the paper towels. The mounts are vertically symmetric, so you can flip the twisting end, mount #1, to either side. Very quiet rolling can be achieved by placing a small strip of masking tape around the passive end of the rod where it enters mount #2.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-11

Resolution:

0.5 x/y, 0.2 z, 1.5 perimeter, 1.0 top/bottom

Infill:

20% on mounts, 50% on rods

Notes:

The threaded rods should have 2-3 layers on the perimeter for rigidity of the threaded area. With 1 layer they will snap with enough tension. With 3 layers and 50% infill the rods appear to be extremely sturdy. The mounts are much more tolerant, and anywhere between 20% and 50% infill should be adequate.

The Magic Wand Delta 3D Printer.... as shown here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XwBe9YSDoow Build volume 280mm x 600mm+

I've had a request to post the stl files for this printer so posting them here now. I don't have the time right now to do a BOM or instructions. I've been refining my magnetic arm design since 2013. My first version was a modified Seemecnc Rostock Max V1. This latest version is my design using readily available components. I am using the seemecnc ezstruder and heated bed.

Misc Notes:

The dxf files were cut with a laser cutter and cnc router. Used 1/4" mdf for top and bottom covers and some 1/4" lite ply for the effector parts.

Magnets for arms (Magic Wands) http://shop.revolutionmachines.com/3-8-95mm-N52-Magnet-Cylinder-Set-12-Piece-ND3-8-12pc.htm

I use 3/8" chrome steel balls with 3mm screws JB welded to them. I use a heat lamp to ensure the JB weld cures properly. There are easier options out there with the studs already attached to the balls.

I've included the Jig I use to make my arms. End caps are ABS and epoxied onto 3/8" carbon fiber tube.

I use RADDS controller with Arduino DUE board and RAPS128 Stepper drivers.

Heated bed is available from seemecnc (280mm printable).

Self locking carriage derived from this and modified to support 9mm belts and MGN15H carriages
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:932959

For the LCD mount user your slicer to make a mirror so you can mount the lcd box on both sides.

Some of the key parts:
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/628
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/523
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/359
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/261 x 6 (idlers at top and steppers)
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/317
MGN15H long body rail (ebay)
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/555 nema 17 corners
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/652 idler
5mm shaft for idlers
https://www.acpsales.com/Pultruted-Carbon-Fiber.html 0.375 OD
e3d V6 hotend

author: pulce15

description.text: sun

print_settings.Notes:: Don't print from PLA. Parts touching potentially hot surfaces (motors, bed, PSU) could deform if printed from PLA.

description.text:
MK2-X is implementation of most of Original Prusa i3 MK2 mechanical and electrical components into metal frame from RebeliX project. The goals are:

  • Significantly more rigid frame, which can be assembled easily and precisely.
  • Reuse as many original parts as possible, especially all X-carriage assembly with extruder.
  • Make basic parameters easily adjustable.

Frame is built from AL profiles 30x30mm (slot width 8mm), frame couplers and steel Y-rods are original from RebeliX project. Frame dimensions are 360x380x390mm (WxDxH). Y-rods are 360mm long. Profile lengths:
X: 360mm (3x)
Y: 320mm (2x)
Z: 330mm (2x)

Linear bearings for Y-carriage are replaced by their longer version LM8LUU. You can also use two LM8UU in row instead of one LM8LUU. You can even use only one LM8UU, in that case put it in center of bearing housing. But with longer bearings the bed is significantly more stable and rigid.
Top end of Z lead screws is secured in 8x22x7 bearings.
You will need some M6 screws and nuts to build the frame and mount printed parts onto it, and some M2,5 screws, M3 screws and self-locking nuts to mount MK2 equipment.

X-home position as well as geometry of Y-carriage can be adjusted by moving Y-rods.
Y-home position can be adjusted by M2,5 screw in Y-belt-holder under the bed.
Y-belt is tightened by simple belt tightener implemented in Y-idler (M2,5 screws).

See also http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1898131 - modifications made for Igus RJMP-01-08 linear bearings.

Important notice:
Parts not listed here (for example whole X axis) are supposed to be taken from your original Mk2 printer without any modifications. If you are building the printer from scratch, you will have to get those parts source files from Prusa's github yourself.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm, 3 perimeters, 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers

Infill:

ABS 15%, PETG 40%

Notes:

To print: 4pcs Y-rod-holder, 2pcs Z-axis-top (one mirrored around X), 2pcs Z-axis-bottom (one mirrored around X), 3pcs Y-bearing-housing, 4pcs al-profile-cover, 2pcs al-profile-cover-with-hole, 2pcs psu-mount-socket, 2pcs psu-mount-plug, all other files as one copy.

Don't print from PLA. Parts touching potentially hot surfaces (motors, bed, PSU) could deform if printed from PLA.

• All parts are designed to be printed easily from ABS without supports and without significant warping.
  • Regarding holes - usually if the hole is rounded, the screw should go easily inside, the hole might need to be finished by drill. If the hole is hexagonal, the screw is supposed to cut the thread there. Don't use drill on this type of holes.
  • Parts are designed with exact dimensions. You may need to do necessary adjustments to fit your printer and type of filament.
  • Some parts contain adhesion pads in corners (e.g. profile covers). They're supposed to be cut away by sharp knife.

Current TODO list
  • Redesign Y belt tightener for more comfort
  • Maybe redesign Y-endstop mount, put Y-endstop on Y-rod-holder to avoid unreasonable dependency of Y-endstop and position of belt pulley on Y-motor.
References

Original Prusa i3 MK2: http://shop.prusa3d.com/en/3d-printers/59-original-prusa-i3-mk2-kit.html
RebeliX project: http://reprap4u.cz/rebelix/ (Czech only)

Changelog
  • 2016-07-27 initial upload
  • 2016-07-28 added LCD mount, new supports replace original ones and all LCD assembly then slides into front rail of the frame
  • 2016-07-28 added Rambo mount
  • 2016-07-28 added AL profile end cover and cover with hole (power lines from PSU to Rambo goes there)
  • 2016-07-29 added assembly guide while still in memory ;-)
  • 2016-07-30 temporarily remover AL profile covers (need redesign), added PSU mount socket and plug
  • 2016-07-30 added new AL profile covers
  • 2016-07-31 finished conversion guide, added few photos of completed printer, cleared "work in progress" flag
  • 2016-08-31 made RebeliX build instructions permanent download link, added original RebeliX corner couplers source STL files
  • 2016-09-17 changed orientation of y-rod-holder
  • 2017-02-12 redesigned some parts to make them work with standard 3030 extrusion T-nuts
  • 2017-05-09 enlarged slots for 3030 T-nuts (was 8mm, now 10mm)
  • 2017-05-09 redesigned z-axis-top and z-axis-bottom: moved down 5mm to avoid colision of probe protector and Z-motor screw, added tightening screw to top part, added hole for adjusting screws
Brief assembly (conversion) guide
  • Assemble the frame using only AL profiles and frame couplers, refer RebeliX guide for details. It's in Czech language, but with a lot of images. You can do it. :-) You can find one at http://s000.tinyupload.com/index.php?file_id=04890953869356069651 Original file can be found at http://reprap4u.cz/navod-na-stavbu-3d-tiskarny-rebelix/ but their download link sometimes doesn't work. When assembling the frame, don't forget to slide in required amount of nuts. They will be needed later. Without them you will have to disassemble the frame to mount printed parts. Also remember that rear edge of vertical profiles should be exactly 115mm from back side of the frame as shown on page 13 of RebeliX guide.
  • Mount Z-axis-bottom (left and right, watch the orientation), tighten.
  • Mount Y-rod-holders, Y-idler, Y-motor-holder, don't tighten (will be adjusted).
  • Slide LM8LUU into housings, mount on Y-carriage, don't tighten.
  • Slide in Y-rods, snap into Y-rod-holders (adjust positions). Fix with zip-ties.
  • Check geometry of Y-carriage (should be parallel with frame), check movement (should move freely in all way in/out), adjust rods if needed, tighten rod holders a little to prevent unwanted moving.
  • Mount Y-motor with endstop. Tighten motor screws, not frame screw.
  • Mount Z-motors (watch cable lengths, longer to the right), tighten.
  • Slide X-carriage assembly on lead screws carefully.
  • Slide in Z rods carefully and stick them in Z-axis-bottoms until they touch motor bodies. You may need to use a little force.
  • Use M3x16 screws and square M3 nuts to assemble z-axis-top parts. Put 8x22x7 bearings into Z-axis-top parts and slide them on lead screws and Z rods (watch orientation). Tighten to the frame. Check geometry, should be perfect. Put M3x30 screws into prepared hole (see images), it will limit vertical travel of the extruder. You can use the screws later for fine-tune of X-axis level.
  • Lay the frame on side, mount heatbed on Y-carriage, mount Y-belt-holder.
  • Assemble Y-belt (path of belt should be straight), tighten a little using adjusting screws on Y-idler. Don't overstress Y-idler. It's a printer, not guitar.
  • Check if Y home adjusting screw clicks Y-endstop when in home position. If not, adjust positions of belt pulley + Y-motor-holder, or heatbed.
  • Return the frame to normal position and check the geometry of Y-carriage. Should be parallel to frame and approx. centered in X axis. Adjust by sliding rod holders in frame. Tighten. Adjust Y belt if needed.
  • Connect cables to Rambo and check function. Both Rambo and PSU are NOT mounted to frame at this step, just laying around to check function and fine adjust geometry. Watch the cables, they shall not collide with moving parts.
  • Check adjustment of home position - do Auto Home command. When finished, Z-probe should stay just above probing point. If not, adjust X by moving Y rods left/right (watch the Y-belt), adjust Y by adjusting screw in belt holder. Recheck home position and repeat until satisfied.
  • === The printer should be able to work at this point.
  • Place Rambo mount on the frame. The bottom side is where M3 holes are closer to edge. Align the height of bottom side around the height of heatbed. Don't put it too low, you won't be able to mount and close the casing door. Don't put it too high either, the cables aren't that long. In particular right Z motor cable is way too short.
  • Mount Rambo in its casing the same way as in Original Prusa i3 MK2.
  • Now comes the tricky part. You will need to replace power cables for longer ones. You need cables 75cm long. Remove black Prusa cover from PSU, drill a hole to bottom side so new cables can go out from bottom side on outer edge, approximately between mains socket and mains switch. Replace cables and put the cover back.
  • Mount printed PSU-mount-plug onto the PSU, use the same screws and holes as on MK2.
  • Slide in printed PSU-mount-sockets.
  • Attach the PSU assembly to the frame by hand all the way down (bottom side touches frame coupler) and mark the position of sockets on Z frame profile.
  • Remove sockets from assembly and mount them on the frame at marked positions.
  • Slide in the PSU.
  • Slide one AL profile cover (with hole) on both cables, put cables through rear traverse frame profile (via center hole) and fit the cover. Slide another cover on both cables on the other side and fit it on the frame.
  • Mount connectors on cables and connect power to the Rambo board.
  • Replace LCD supports by new ones, connect LCD cables at LCD side and then slide both supports into rail in front traverse frame profile.
  • Fit two AL profile covers on front frame profile, another two on top frame profile.
  • Finish cable management. I used some RebeliX cable clips combined with zip ties.
  • Done. Feel free to make additional gadgets yourself. :-)

comments.author: Nitrogen777

comments.text:
The problem is most likely in X axis. It's not horizontal, or it is twisted, or its length is not correct.
Remove top z axis holders, hold Z rods by hand and try to get X carriage to the top again (as high as possible). Then compare Z axis rods distance at the top and at the bottom of Z axis. It should be the same.

comments.text: NEMA 17. For X, Y, and extruder I'd reccomend decently sized, but for the Z its essential you get pretty small ones, unless you get ones with the integreated leadscrew. I do not have integrated leadscrews and I ran into problems with the hotend not going low enough (hitting the motors) so if you dont get integrated leadscrews, make sure the motors arent too tall.

comments.text:
Ahoj, na jedné z mých tiskáren jsem měl kombinaci klasických NEMA motorů a trapézových šroubů spojených pružnou spojkou a nedělalo to dobrotu při tisku objektů s hodně přejezdy a retrakcemi v kombinaci s velkou hodnotou Lift-Z. Na tom výsledku to bylo vidět. Originál MK2 má ty šrouby přímo integrované do motorů (tvoří jejich hřídel). Pokud se použijou kluzné ložiska, tak je to ještě markantnější, mají větší tření.
Použij pevnou spojku, klidně tištěnou, je to jednoduchý díl, který nakreslíš za 10 minut. Nejlíp to měl řešené původní Rebelix tou klasickou PVC hadičkou narvanou na osu a závitovku, pružilo to a zároveň to nemělo axiální vůli a jako bonus to skoro nic nestálo. Bohužel se to blbě realizuje, když motor má 5mm a trapézovka 8mm.
Nouzově se dá použít i ta pružná spojka, když se uvnitř dorazí osa motoru úplně těsně k trapézovce a když nahoře zajistíš, aby se trapézovka nemohla samovolně vysunout směrem nahoru (při současném natažení té pružné spojky).

comments.text:
Well that's quite tough question. :-) Unfortunately I didn't build up any BOM during building phase of the frame so I haven't got any record of consumed screws. Most of M6 were M6x6 and M6x8. Too long screws will collide with 3030 extrusions. I made myself supplies of M6x6, M6x8, M6x10 and M6x12 (50 pcs each) and used them as needed.
M3 - I really don't know. Some for Y bearing housings, some for Y-belt-holder (original ones are too short), one longer for Y-idler pulley, maybe original fits ok. I don't remember any more M3. Edit: of course - Rambo case and PSU need some M3 too. And I remember I reused some M3 from original kit frame.
M2.5 are used only as adjustment screws on Y-idler and Y-belt-holder, I think they are M2.5x15

comments.text: davtr: I found a couple of issues that impacted me with your files.  The z-axis-top and z-axis-bottom did not allow the sliding T-Nut (one T-nut on one and two T-nuts on the other) to pull in tight.  The plastic on the back that is made to go into the slot to help with alignment does not allow the sliding T-Nut, also with its guide, to pull tightly against the 3030.  I removed the part from the 3030, tightened it lightly, drew a line with a Sharpie, and used a Demel and file to remove the offending plastic.  Also, the carriages on the left and right that hold the rods for the x axis...  Mine were very tight, to the point we could not get one rod seated (possibly caught and edge and rolled some plastic as I was pressing the rods in), have since broken a piece because of pounding, and will need to cut the plastic off to recover the rods.  You might want to consider some small 'observation' holes along the path where the rods seat.  Maybe I could see in each hole, how much progress I am making.  If not visually, maybe with a stick pin or sewing needle.  Other than that, an awesome set of parts!!!  Very well built.
comments.author: mikewrobel

comments.text: The z-axis-top and z-axis-bottom did not allow the sliding T-Nut (one T-nut on one and two T-nuts on the other) to pull in tight.
comments.author: mikewrobel

comments.text: Dave,  x-end parts were the correct size.  I needed to 1) clean out some debris from the holes, and 2) taper the end of my rods with a little belt sander.  I use parallel clamps in my woodworking.  I took two of them and gradually squeezed the part together.  SOOOO much better than pounding and breaking that protrusion off.  Also, I stuck an unsharpened pencil into the hole, marked the distance with a Sharpie, then transferred the mark to the rod.  Now I knew I was seated completely.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text:
Of course, it is actually very easy to redefine Z axis length. Just make the frame taller, get longer Z smooth rods, longer Z lead screws, probably longer cables to extruder, and redefine max Z height in firmware.
But you will most likely be unable to print ABS that high since bed heating is very ineffective in higher Z unless the printer is in enclosed environment.

comments.text: I am not using an PRUSA MK2 bed, but rather looking at 200x300 or 300x300.  Is there simple math to calculate the length of the 3030 (x and y) and the rods (x and y)?

comments.text:
Just correspondingly enlarge particular dimension. Current frame allows use of 250x200 heatbed. If you want to use 300x200, add 50 to X axis. If you want to use 300x300, add 50 to X axis and 100 to Y axis. Don't forget to get longer smooth rods.
Also consider conversion to 24V heatbed, that large bed may drag too much current to be fed by RAMBo at 12V. Limit is 15A.

comments.text:
No, igus parts are not mandatory. This project is designed as rework of Original i3 MK2. You are supposed to take parts from your original MK2 printer bought from Prusa Research. Only modified parts or new parts necessary to build the frame are included in this project.
If you want to build the printer from scratch, you will have to search Prusa github repository for rest of the printed parts.
comments.author: mikewrobel

comments.text: Thank you, Dave.  I missed that in my reading.  I will find the MK2 parts and sort that out.  I am very impressed with the quality of your parts and how you lay them out so they work with gravity.  I do want to try the Igus bearings, but want to get the basic printer together first so that I can see what happens with the Igus.  I have seen a couple of builds online where users abandon the Igus bearings.  I am not sure if some people get a bad batch or they just don't implement them right (possibly making decisions about lubricants that are faulty).  As an engineer, I actually want to understand the difference and then choose what is appropriate for me.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text:
Igus bearings work well if they're properly mounted. The problem of MK2 is that bed bearings and X-carriage bearings are mounted using zip ties. If you make them too tight, the bearings get too squeezed on smooth rods and stop moving freely.
The problem with bed bearings is solved by Y-bearing-holder (it prevents squeezing of bearings). X-carriage bearings should be tighten little by little until there is no play on smooth rods, but not more. Then they work well. I'm quite satisfied with them. No lubrication needed. I can see no wear after 2 months of printing.
comments.author: mikewrobel

comments.author: 3D_JumpingJack

comments.text:
There is nothing about Z axis calibration since the pitch of lead screw is well known as well as steps/rev parameter of stepper motor. You simply calculate steps/mm for Marlin and you're done.
For MK2 with Tr8x8 lead screw and 3200 steps/rev Nema17 motor it is 400 steps/mm for Z axis. Exactly, no further calibration.
comments.author: 3D_JumpingJack

comments.author: mazterlee

comments.text: When calibration routine asks for moving x-carriage all way up, you should move it a bit lower. On MK2, x-carriage is moved all way up to make it aligned horizontally with Z frame. Knowing this, you should move x-carriage up approximately to the height where upper edge of x-end printed parts meets bottom edge of Z frame upper part. Then make X steel rods aligned (parallel) with Z frame (rotate Z lead screws by hand). Then you are done with alignment and calibration routine can continue.

comments.text: Thanks for the reply.  I'd expect that if you increase the rigidity of the frame you could increase print speeds, right?  At the point you are at you could probably increase print speeds a fair amount, but with a bit more effort you could probably make the print speeds vastly higher.  This is the core reason I am interested in this project, I'd love to double or greater the printing speed of a prusa i3 mk2 and I assume the bigger piece of the puzzle is frame rigidity.  I also imagine active cooling for the steppers, maybe a larger blower.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text:
There is a limitation of print speeds based on hotend performance. There is discussion thread about it at prusa3d forums, unfortunately I couldn'f find it at the moment. The problem is that E3D V6 is capable of melting specified given volume of filament per second. This determines maximum print speed regardless of frame rigidity.
If you want to increase print speeds way above this limit, you will have to use E3D Volcano hotend.
comments.author: waterling

comments.text: Well I am sorry to say but you have absolutely no idea what you are talking about.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text: I have considered using the volcano, it's only 8.5mm longer.  I imagine that perhaps it is viable to lengthen the Z height a fair bit, maybe a lot.  I've also considered a pre-heat chamber or stage for a filament to get the filament a around 10c below it's glass transition temperature.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text: You will still have to play a bit with motors power and acceleration settings, to avoid problems with skipped steps. It will most likely fail in current silent mode setup and maybe even in highpower setup as well. Heatbed is quite heavy so inertia forces will be rather high.

comments.text: I've never used silent mode, doubt I ever would.  I suspect active cooling and some heatsinks could increase the power capabilities of this setup a great deal.

title: BigBox Top-Mounted Filament/Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When printing with NinjaFlex, the up-from-the-back tube really doesn't help, so I made this to top mount the spool (easier than the rear mount anyway).
This is made to width for the ninjaflex spools, you can change the width to accommodate. Rod is a piece of 3/4" PVC trimmed to fit.
I suspect you could fit 4-6 of these on a machine.

Edit: This is apparently only meant for the right side of the machine, due to different depths of the top piece of perspex. Ah well.

Note: This is meant to print with supports under each of the hooked arms and under the archway between spool legs. Also, there is a pocket on the frame of the spool holder on the outside of the machine - this is meant to eventually have something hooked onto it like a tool holder, etc. Do with it what you will.

If you need to know the position of a shaft, this encoder can do what you want. You will need to line up a row of surface-mount LEDs on one side and phototransistors on the other. The output is in binary from 0-127. The outer row of holes is the 'clock', that is, the data is valid only when light is shining through one of these holes. You can decode the wheel either with a microcontroller or simply use an 8 bit latch. I designed this wheel to provide feedback to a servomotor driving a tracking antenna.

A good printer is needed to print this!

title: Slimline Compact dual twin 30mm fan shroud for e3d v6

description.text:
Further Update: I have included here the latest version of this fan shroud by Jinx. It includes adjustable height for the print fan sides. One version has holes to mount a DC42 IR sensor.

UPDATE: Things move fast; Jinx of the Reprap community has remixed this version already and has improved the fixing with a bolt rather than cable tie, and has made the hot end fan mounting face flush with the part cooling fan bases for easier printing. Please use his version instead. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1693413

This is a super compact remix of the fan holder by saldot. I wanted a dual part fan with hot end cooler shroud to fit an e3d v6 but which would fit almost under my Kossel effector. The original for my setup is too wide and cuts into my print volume, as the fans hit the belts if I need to move nearer the edge of the bed.

This version is as small as I thought I could go and still get the geometry to work.

Use a cable tie on the hot end cooler on the opposite side to the fans to retain the shroud in place, it might be tight enough without but mine creaked a bit when being stretched over the heatsink so I used one for added safety.

The screw holes for the fans came out slightly tight alignment-wise when I printed it but a little persuasion and they went in fine.

Getting the orientation of the heater block relative to the shroud is a little tricky but there are angles that work.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I printed it orientated as it is presented here with plenty of support. I might see if I can do a version which has a flatter side so less support is needed,
Using tinkercad and using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1676276 as inspiration.

title: Triangular Pencil Grip: Mold for Silicone Casting
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Make a 3D Printed 3-part mold for silicone casting projects. For this project I used a Smooth-On brand Ecoflex product, which is a 2-part mix that cures over 4 hours after being combined and mixed. (https://www.smooth-on.com/product-line/ecoflex/)

Wrap some rubber bands around the channels to keep the sections tight during the curing phase.

I used the toaster oven for a quick, 10-minute cure, at a low heat (read more details at the Smooth-On website). I did this because my PLA print was porous enough to let the low viscosity liquid silicone seep through the gaps. You don't want it to ooze out over 4 hours!

IMPORTANT: Make sure not to cure in an oven that you would also cook food in later. Make this your new "science oven".

Find the design files on TinkerCAD. ( https://tinkercad.com/things/a9I87Zb1Phd )

You can remove the triangular wedge negative and insert your own "hole" shape to customize the grip design.

print_settings.Notes:: if flat: required more support, but the horizontal bar will be more resistant.

description.text:
You have a Raspberry Pi 2 to fix in your product case ?

  • when you have to fix it flat, no problem ... just 4 spacers+4 screws et voila !
  • but when it comes to fix it on one side/edge ... more complex ; this is where this fixture is handy

it permits to fix it in your product box on any of 3 sides, either over the board as Under the board, with plenty of locations for srews or nuts.

TIP: if you need it as light as possible (FPV or others): choose the side you need, then at slice time, place this one down on the plate (z=0) and during printing or during the slicer setting, stop the printing 10mm before the end

Here printed with "Thingiverse Blue" :)
There is a logo, but inside & not visible when board is in place.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Raft: depending on the sealing with the plate, especially with ABS ; but should not be required here.
Mind the orientation:

  • if flat: required more support, but the horizontal bar will be more resistant.
  • if the "bottom of the U" down: less supports, but the bar becomes fragile; Only if you do not need that side on the fixture.

Made with Solidworks

You can dowload all original SW files & assembly at http://innovation.world

Free for you to modify, fork or produce at large scale with other means (a link would be appreciated)

print_settings.Notes:: "5_target_cooling_fan_split.stl" model was splitted, for more easy print. You will need to glue together it (=

title: Anet A6 - Frankenstein (E3D v6 / Volcano)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's a live! My monster, called like Frankenstein ((=

All what you need is only E3Dv6 standard extruder with his fan. Second fan and bearings you already have in original Anet A6 extruder.

Required bowden filament feeder. If you have PTFE tube and fittings, you no need to buy anything more, all can be made from original Anet A6 extruder.

This carriage allowing to use basic e3d v6 hot end block and volcano hot end block. You can set different height by moving central part (radiator holder).

Two sides cooling provide better quality of print. Large air flow channels. Cooling of radiator of extruder, also made with flow simulations, and has correct flow path.

Fast and easy belt tension. Connection without screeds.

Some links I used:
E3D v6 kit (with volcano), PTFE tube, 40mm fan, GT2 belt, linear bearings (or use olds from Anet).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Anet A6 Prusa

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

"5_target_cooling_fan_split.stl" model was splitted, for more easy print. You will need to glue together it (=

Glue together splitted parts by ABS juice.

Probably you will be need to clean some connections of parts (especially after ABS shrinkage). All connecting parts must be connected easily.

Please, first, see assembly video.
https://youtu.be/Nh6OMUOL_58

Also you can see my not profesional video of assembly :P
https://youtu.be/yt15mqUs__A
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Nh6OMUOL_58" ></iframe>

If you want to support me and if you want to get cashbacks on Aliexpress and others, check this: http://epngo.bz/cashback_index/v1nphb

Thank you (;

comments.text:
• Yes i printed it in PLA and it works fine.
  • When printing more complex objects (even without retraction) i am experiencing a lot of filament jams. those jams happen right before the heatbrake so i guess my filament cooling needs to be improved. such kind of problems i never had when using the direct drive. yes, the printing process looks a lot faster but for some reason it still has the same overall duration on those models i reprinted so far.
    I think the major advantage of the E3D hotend vs the original hotend is the difference in printing-quality which suprised me a lot. before i used it i thought that my quality was already really nice but the E3D took it to another level. As additional bonus the printing-process has become a bit quieter.

title: Brick Dice Tower with Fold-Up Wooden Drawbridges

description.text:
The newest version of the dice tower! This dice tower has extra detail added with brick throughout the tower and wooden grain added on the fold-up drawbridges.

Remixed from garyacrowellsr's 'Remixed Angular Dice Tower, with trays'

This one is a real challenge to print, so make one and test out your printer today!

Check out our Etsy for all of our 3D printed awesomeness!
https://www.etsy.com/shop/CarryTheWhat

You'll want to print these at a fairly high resolution (at least .2mm) because of the steep angle and all the detail, otherwise it could be droopy.

Print the following pieces:

1x tower.stl
2x tray.stl
4x pin_1.stl

Snap the pins into the holes on the tray, facing inwards, and then snap the tray to the tower. Repeat on the opposite side, and you're ready to play!

EDIT: It looks like some people are having trouble with the pins. I print the pins in ABS and they work well, but it's quite possible the pins don't print well in PLA.

description.text:
Hi!

10Print is a classic in creative coding. A Commodore64 one-line program that generates a random sequence of slash and antislash painting something like a maze.

This is my printable version. Developed in OpenScad.

In customizer you can choose a size for your grid.
You can also choose the random seed for reproducing the same sequence if needed.

Customizer doesn't have a title option. The example printed comes as an STL in thing files.

Also included a scad file (ZIPPED) with title.

Hope you enjoy it

Have fun!

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Supports:

No

Notes:

Tested with PLA at 0.2 resolution and 50% Infill

Printed test at 50% scale-XY keeping 100% in Z (2 mms).

Changed color after first millimeter from black to white.

10 Print it's a good starting point for programmers looking for something artistic and also a good inspiration for new designs.

Easy to change for generating different patterns just changin the slashs with other figures.

Look at http://10print.org/ for an awesome book (free in PDF) about this fantastic algorithm

title: Lush shampoo bar tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My wife uses shampoo bar's from the store Lush. The problem is when you buy them, they do not come with any container to hold them.

At first we tried storing them in the little black pots that other Lush products come in. I drilled some holes in the bottom of the black pot to let the water drain out. The pot helped to stop the shampoo bars from getting wet while taking a shower but the drain holes did not allow enough air to fully dry the shampoo bars.

I made up these trays to support the shampoo bars inside the little black pots and allow the water to drain off easier. You place the tray with the spikes up. What works out nice is that the spikes allows you to stand the shampoo bar up vertical if you need it to dry quicker.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Drill some holes in the bottom of the black pots.

Just remove from build platform and place inside of the Lush's little black pots.
Designed with Tinkercad.

title: Extended control dial for MonoPrice Select Mini/Malyan M200

description.text:
This is an adoption of the Better Dial http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1677768

I modified the Better Dial to be used with the original dial to give it a more polished look. It still sticks out plenty to grab the sides for more control but can still spin on the face of the dial as well. The original dial snaps on snuggly with no need for gluing.

I used clear PLA filament printed with 10% infill, it gives a nice back light from the blue LED lights.

UPDATE: I reduced the depth of the bottom hole so less likely to bottom out.

description.text:
This is a housing component designed to hold the Adafruit TSL2561 Light Sensor. It is intended for use on FTC robots.

It is recommended to use 2-56 screws to secure the circuit board to the housing. If you printer makes holes slightly smaller, you should be able to put threads into the mounting holes. The outer mounting holes have 8mm spacing and are designed to use 6-32 screws. Again, the holes might be too small, so you can frill them out with a #27 drill bit to create a through hole (or create threads).

Update 7/30/16: Added a model designed to hold LEDs. We've used these 5mm LEDs from Vetco: http://www.vetco.net/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=15009 The LED holes should be bored out with a 5mm drill, then glued into place. They can then be wired to a digital channel port on the Device Interface Module. We suggest wiring them in parallel with a 100 ohm resistor attached to each to compensate different amounts of light emitting from each LED.

Notes:

You will need supports if you are printing the model with LED mounting holes.

description.text:
PTFE LM8UU replacement

Disclaimer

This bearing uses PTFE as a sliding surface, and is known to wear much quicker than drylin, or steel ball bearings on a hardened steel shaft. This is only proposed as a temporary measure, or for low loading applications.

I personally will be using it for a pen plotter, which will have a low loading mass.

Introduction

This printed bearing casing and cutting tool allow the user to print a very low friction bearing that will fit normal LM8UU bearing holders. PTFE bowden tube is cut using a printed fixture and stanley blade to slice a 4mm ID and 2mm OD bowden tube in half axially

Requirements

  • Stanley blade
  • 66mm length of 4mm OD 2mm OD bowden tube per bearing

Instuctions

  • Print the PTFE cutting tool
  • Insert the PTFE tube into the tool until it stops at the bottom of the recess
  • Using the stanley blade, cut flush with the top of the cutting tool to leave a piece of PTFE in the cutting tool (this piece will be 22mm long)
  • Slice down both the helical grooves down the side of the tool, cutting the PTFE tube in half - you may need to grip the tube at the top to stop it twisting in the tool
  • Pull the PTFE tube out of the tool
  • Slice off the bottom 2mm of the two pieces of tube where the two halves are joined
  • Repeat twice with the remaining 44mm of PTFE tubing so you have 6 halves of PTFE tube
  • Print the bearing casing
  • Insert the PTFE pieces into the bearing casing grooves on inner bore. The PTFE might need a bit of persuasion to fit and so use a thin nose pair of pliers if its a tight fit. Slicing a few mm off the end of the PTFE pieces will compensate for any less than ideal bridging on the inside of the bearing casing
  • Slide onto an 8mm linear rod and run up and down to check movement

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 ideally

Infill:

60%-100%

Notes:

Use minimum 2x perimeters on bearing casing

Check bridging moves on top of grooves for possible sagging

print_settings.Notes:: Note: Not all printers will print the same so the snug and loose fits are not guaranteed. The CAD files have been uploaded so feel free to experiment with dimensions as needed.

description.text:
After looking through all the designs of hex bit holders, I didn't find one that suited my needs perfectly so I modeled my own. It is a 4 x 15 grid giving you 60 spots for your 1/4" hex driver bits. The two tiers in front fit the shorter bits while the back two rows fit the taller bits. I have uploaded two versions of the model: one that fits each bit snugly and one that fits a little more loosely. If you prefer to be able to pull each bit out with one hand then try the loose fit and if you want them to be secure enough that they won't fall out when you turn the part over, try the snug fit. This is my first upload so I'm welcome to feedback. Thanks!

Also, please post pictures of your prints!

EDIT 12/1/2016
I re-uploaded the two parts after adding a chamfer I left out originally on the front left edge of the parts. The original posted parts' function was not affected by this. This change is purely cosmetic.
I also included the .ipt and .igs along with the .stl so you can tweak it in Autodesk Inventor or most other CAD software. Let me know if there are any changes you would like to see!

As always, feedback is welcome and appreciated, and please post any makes if you print your own. Cheers!

EDIT 12/10/2016

I just added a version of the loose fitting and snug fitting models that has the back two rows reduced down to the same internal height as the first two rows. Each row is still set up in tiers so it has the "stadium seating" design. This reduces the amount of material and time needed for the print and should function the same way.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this with Cura using 0.1mm layer height, 20% grid infill, 0.4mm line width, and 0.8mm wall thickness. I suspect a 0.2mm or even a 0.3mm layer height and a lower infill percentage would be just as functional and should cut down on print time significantly.

Note: Not all printers will print the same so the snug and loose fits are not guaranteed. The CAD files have been uploaded so feel free to experiment with dimensions as needed.

Autodesk Inventor 2017

This is a solid .ipt file designed in Autodesk Inventor 2017 with basic extrusions and chamfers. Tweak as you see fit!

title: X to Y Axis alignment/leveling tool

description.text:
This is just a blatant copy/remake of an awesome little tool! Just a tad taller!

Original item - (red one in the images)
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280974

The original was great but for one thing, after I added a glass bed it ended up being shorter than the end stop for the Z axis. SO I made a slightly taller one.

Just did a write up and video on use of this tool...
http://3dprintingllama.blogspot.com/2017/04/square-level-x-and-y-axis-before.html

what it does- It checks the alignment of the X axis rods to the rods in the Y axis to make sure they are square/level to each other. Use before leveling the bed to get a MUCH better and more accurate leveling.

Clip on the Y rods and lower BY HAND the Z down till the X rod just touches, go to other rod on Y axis and adjust..

never do this with power, you can severely damage the printer by bending the rods if you use the motors!!.

https://youtu.be/DYywCMh4U0k

comments.text: Would printing 2 of them simplify the process a lot? I do something similar with a small rod, i have a screw in which i reference it and level it not against Y rods, but against frame.
comments.author: truhlik_fredy

comments.text: no.. these printers can be inaccurate even though it's a very small amount (reason we get things like Z-ribbing) when trying to adjust in micro amounts like this, having 2 tools even a hair different will likely throw you out some.
comments.author: truhlik_fredy

comments.text: What about crosschecking, calibrate with 2, then swap them and confirm, if you feel difference, use just one. If it feels indentical even after swap it's probably good indication it might be accurate? I'm using 1 tools as well for accuracy reasons (and effort, to make 2 tools), but thinking out loud.
comments.author: Thomllama

comments.text: sure... I guess..
